newsitem.title: AUSTRALIA: BHP says average copper cost US$0.57/lb.
newsitem.headline: BHP says average copper cost US$0.57/lb.

text.p: The Broken Hill Pty Co Ltd said on Monday that its average cost of producing cathode copper was 57 U.S. cents per pound in 1996/97 (June-May).
The average cost is below earlier estimates provided by BHP which ran up to about 85 cents per pound, based in part on BHP's recently acquired Magma copper operations in North America.

Speaking at briefing seminar in Melbourne, Jim Lewis, executive general manager of BHP Copper, said the company's "one-time" A$550 million write-down in some North American copper assets, announced on Friday, was timely.
Copper currently fetches about US$1.11 a pound on world markets.
Lewis said he was encouraged by outlooks for demand for copper for the remainder of 1997 and into early 1998.
But while world demand was moving up, supplies were also increasing, Lewis said.
"At the end of the day our real issue is to push costs down whatever the price," he said.
BHP is the world's number two copper producer behind the state-owned Codelco group in Chile.
BHP shares were 20 cents firmer at A$19.35 at 1.00 p.m. (0300 GMT).
